Title: Is $\frac{3^n+5^n+7^n}{15}$ only prime if $n$ is prime?
Content: Let $f(n)=3^n+5^n+7^n$ It is easy to show that $\ 15\mid f(n)\ $ if and only if $\ n\ $ is odd. I searched for prime numbers of the form $g(n):=\frac{3^n+5^n+7^n}{15}$ with odd $n$ and found the following $n$ leading to a prime number : $$7,17,61,71,457,8111$$ All those numbers are prime numbers. Can we show that this is a necessary condition ? The cases $3\mid n$ and $5\mid n$ are clear because $\frac{3^n+5^n+7^n}{15}$ is divisble by $\ 3\ $ and $\ 5\ $ respectively, but what about $\ g(77)\ $ which smallest prime factor is $\ 463\ $ and other cases ?
